item.title: By: entirelyuseless
item.dc:creator: entirelyuseless
item.description:
It is not illegal to know more than the insurance company, if you are not responsible for causing the thing you are insuring against.
I know someone who bought temporary health insurance because he was living in a house where two people had just been hospitalized with a potentially infectious disease, with their hospital stays costing thousands of dollars. Two days later, he came down with the same thing. It was entirely legal: he had to sign a statement saying that at the time he bought the insurance, he had no symptoms which would cause a reasonable person to consult a doctor. It was the complete truth. He simply knew that he was likely to get sick for other reasons.
The insurance company paid for his hospital stay, as required by their contract.

item.title: By: dreeves
item.dc:creator: dreeves
item.description:
@Liam, I see, yeah, I guess the way to disambiguate it is to say $100k is the max *coverage* but the $2k is a bonus or penalty on top of whatever the coverage is (I think that was the natural interpretation!). Or scrap the "max coverage" part. $100k is just the max you can write down.
Oh, and note that even if the insurance company pays $99k and $101k they are in fact paying the max of $100k *per claim*. So just think of the $2k not as an adjustment to the coverage but as a transfer between the two claimants.

item.title: By: Liam Carton
item.dc:creator: Liam Carton
item.description:
@dreeves. Sorry, but I don't agree. the satement in the original puzzel was that there was a 100K cap on the payment. Therefore my assertion that 100K was the maximum payout is true. So if person a says 100K and person b says 99K then a will get 98K and b will get 100K, NOT 101K. So they go for 99K for absolutely no benefit!
Therefore the logical choice is for both a and b to quote 100K.
Sorry, but that is what the puzzel says. Of course b could go 98K, but again they gain nothing over quoting 100K, except to screw a out of 4,000. Still not rational.
Cheers
Liam

item.title: By: JoeK
item.dc:creator: JoeK
item.description: The optimal algorithm I can use, under the assumption that the opponent is equally rational and will cooperate, is to choose $100K. If I calculate the expected mutual value of each possible choice given the assumption of a cooperating counter-party, total utility is maximized at $100K. Further, "Not being a dick" is an important term in my personal utility function. So I really don't care if I get 97 and she gets 101, or whatever.
